Discharge Summary

Patient: ___
Gender: Male
Age: 70
Admission Date: February 10, 2024
Discharge Date: February 14, 2024

Reason for Admission: ___ was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of cough, shortness of breath, hemoptysis, and fever. These symptoms were indicative of pneumonia, and an initial chest X-ray revealed consolidation in the left lower lobe, confirming the diagnosis of lobar pneumonia, unspecified organism.

Hospital Course: Upon admission, the patient was initiated on empirical antibiotic therapy with intravenous Amoxicillin and was administered Paracetamol as needed for fever. Over the course of his stay, his inflammatory markers showed progressive improvement. The C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, initially elevated at 60 mg/L, decreased steadily to 20 mg/L by February 13, 2024, and his white blood cell (WBC) count trended down from 12 x10^9/L to 7 x10^9/L. Vital signs also stabilized, with the patient's temperature normalizing and oxygen saturation improving to 98% on room air by February 13.

Treatment Regimen: During his hospitalization, ___ was managed with a regimen of antibiotics, initially with intravenous administration, which was transitioned appropriately to oral antibiotics as his condition improved. He was maintained on Atorvastatin nightly for coexisting conditions. Following the improvement in his clinical status, the patient's medications were adjusted accordingly, switching from intravenous to oral Amoxicillin on February 13.

Recovery and Discharge: By February 12, 2024, the patient's temperature had normalized, and his oxygen saturation levels were stable. The medical team planned to switch to oral antibiotics, anticipating discharge. By February 14, 2024, ___ was considered medically fit for discharge based on the resolution of acute symptoms and continued improvement, as evidenced by declining CRP and WBC levels.

Discharge Instructions: On discharge, ___ was instructed to continue oral antibiotics for five more days. He was also advised to follow up in the outpatient clinic in two weeks for re-evaluation. It is important for him to remain vigilant for any recurrent symptoms or adverse reactions and to seek medical attention promptly if needed.

We are pleased with the progress ___ has made during his hospital stay and expect a continued positive recovery at home. Always consult with your doctor should any questions or concerns arise during the recovery period. If you have additional inquiries, please do not hesitate to contact the hospital team.

Sincerely,

Dr. ___
